chapter.title: Host Clusters
chapter.para:
The cluster specific elements which may be contained in the cluster description are as follows:
cpu A server CPU reference which defines which CPU type must be supported by all hosts in the cluster. See
data_center A reference to the data center of which this cluster is a member. See
For example:
chapter.screen: <cluster id="0" href="clusters/0"> <name>Default</name> <description>The default server cluster</description> <cpu id="Intel Xeon 45nm Core2"/> <data_center id="d70d5e2d-b8ad-494a-a4d2-c7a5631073c4" href="datacenters/d70d5e2d-b8ad-494a-a4d2-c7a5631073c4"/> </cluster>
chapter.para: When creating a new cluster, the name, cpu id and datacenter id properties are required. Only the name, description and cpu id elements may be updated post-creation.

section.title: CPUs
section.para: Each cluster is configured with a minimal CPU type which all hosts in that cluster must support. Guests running on hosts within the cluster all run on this CPU type, ensuring that every guest can be live migrated to any host within the cluster.

RHEV has a set of CPU types to choose from when configuring a cluster. The rel="cpus" link obtained from the entry point URI (see ) allows the list of CPU types to be queried. Each CPU has the following properties:
id An opaque identifier for the CPU model
level An indication as to the relative priority/preference for the CPUs in the list. Higher is better
flags A list of the CPU flags supported by the CPU
For example:
section.screen:
GET /cpus HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xml
<cpus> <cpu id="Intel Xeon w/o XD/NX"> <level>2</level> <flags> <flag>vmx</flag> <flag>sse2</flag> </flags> </cpu> <cpu id="Intel Xeon"> <level>3</level> <flags> <flag>vmx</flag> <flag>sse2</flag> <flag>nx</flag> </flags> </cpu> ... </cpus>
